questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP -
You suspect that multiple unrelated security events have occurred on several nodes on a corporate network. You must review all logs and correlate events when necessary to discover each security event by clicking on each node. Only select corrective actions if the logs shown a security event that needs remediation. Drag and drop the appropriate corrective actions to mitigate the specific security event occurring on each affected device.
Instructions:
The Web Server, Database Server, IDS, Development PC, Accounting PC and Marketing PC are clickable. Some actions may not be required and each actions can only be used once per node. The corrective action order is not important. If at any time you would like to bring back the initial state of the simulation, please select the Reset button. When you have completed the simulation, please select the Done button to submit. Once the simulation is submitted, please select the
Next button to continue.
//IMG//

Select and Place:
//IMG//

discussion.content:
IDS -> WAF
Dev PC -> NIPS
Accounting PC -> HIPS
Marketing PC -> Application Whitelisting
Web Server -> WAF, Server side Validation, Secure Coding
Database -> HIPS

comments.content:
Each actions can only be used once per node so am thinking
Web server- Server side Validation
Database- Secure Coding
I have been looking at this for 30mins now. Honestly am confuse now. Please share the answers if you can. Thank you

Dev PC is doing an NMAP scan. Can have HIPS on it.
Web Server - logs show SQL Injection. Could do either validation or WAF
You won’t necessarily put WAF on a server. So for web server it should be server side validation.

Wait, I don't get it... . These logs make absolutely no sense at all. Some are for completely different devices even. In addition, the question clearly states that we should ONLY apply a security control if the logs indicate a security event... . That almost sounds as if some should not have a security control.

Web Server (10.10.10.10) -> SERVER SIDE VALIDATION (Could potentially also be WAF or SECURE CODING).
Database Server (10.10.10.12) -> I'm not necessarily seeing something wrong here.
IDS -> Nothing, because an IDS is passive. Potentially, we could replace it with an IPS though... ?
Development PC (172.30.0.5) -> Logs are those of the print server??
Accounting PC (172.30.0.3) -> Again, I'm not necessarily seeing something wrong here.
Marketting PC (172.30.0.2) -> APPLICATION WHITELISTING

Left over options:
NIPS, WAF, HIPS, SECURE CODING
I totally agree

IDS=waf
dev pc=nips
accounting pc=hips
marketing pc=application whitelisting
web server= server side validation
data base= secure coding
all can be used just once. thank you

discussion.content:
Use this link to see the logs clearly 
https://cloudtech.how/comptia/cysa-cs0-001-q-002/
This question was on the exam (october-2020)

"Some actions may not be required..." -> for me this means that we don't need use all the actions.

"...and each actions can only be used once per node." -> once per node means that we can't repeat the same workaround on others, right?

"The corrective action order is not important." -> and this suggests that some of them need more than a solution? (a). Or means that it doesn't matter the order of devices in which you apply the solution? (b)

Why is everyone so sure you can only put one remediation strategy in? 
"... each actions can only be used once per node." implies that multiple actions can be used?

So here is my take on this.
IDS - nothing bad I see apart from a downloads/windows
Dev PC - doing a NMAP scan. NIPS can be used
Accnt PC - is accessing security group config. HIPS can be utilised
Marketing PC - torrent. Whitelisting
Web server - can see web crawling being done by spiders/crawlers. Can also see an instance of SQLi. WAF can be utilised
Database - can’t really see anything bad

comments.content:
I think this is the right answer.

IDS is a normal GET traffic, no crawlers or web atks.
DB is also normal unlike Accnt PC that has security group mgmt logs.

discussion.content: I cant read the choices for the first task, the print is too small.

questions.question_text: A company wants to update its acceptable use policy (AUP) to ensure it relates to the newly implemented password standard, which requires sponsored authentication of guest wireless devices. Which of the following is MOST likely to be incorporated in the AUP?

choices.D: The network should authenticate all guest users using 802.1x backed by a RADIUS or LDAP server.
choices.C: Guests using the wireless network should provide valid identification when registering their wireless devices.
choices.A: Sponsored guest passwords must be at least ten characters in length and contain a symbol.
choices.B: The corporate network should have a wireless infrastructure that uses open authentication standards.

discussion.content: c is correct. this is where the guest device is redirected, after connecting to the ssid, to a splash page requesting proper id of the user
This question was in the exam :)
Register ID to sponsor
The answer is C, provision of Guest access separately from corporate network.

Acceptable Use Policy (AUP) outlines what hte organization considers to be appropriate use of it's resources. The goal of the policy is to ensure employee productivity while limiting potential organizational liability resulting from inappropriate use of the organization's assets.
In other words they want to make sure that guest wireless devices are checked to avoid misuse of the companies stuff?
A - Passwords can be shared? Also I don't feel like it answers the question.
B - Anyone can use it no?
C - "requires a guest user to provide valid identification when registering their wireless devices and an employee to validate their need for access" So people cant use and abuse company stuff
D - Iuno what that does in relation to this question.

I was confused between A and C. AUP is a document policy that a user must agree to for access to corporate network. I think "A" falls more in password policy. A sponsored guest must have a valid identification to use corporate network, therefore the answer is C. 
I think B and D have nothing to do with AUP.

It's C, but I don't understand why it's C (https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/solutions/Enterprise/Borderless_Networks/Unified_Access/BYOD_Design_Guide/BYOD_Guest_Wireless_Access.html#pgfId-1004417)
I think the correct answer here is D, Open authen means everyone can connect
B - OATH is the standard when it comes to wireless auth
Anyone can explain this? Sponsored authentication means the guest must have a sponsor which will authorize the wireless connection/device.

questions.question_text: A nuclear facility manager determined the need to monitor utilization of water within the facility. A startup company just announced a state-of-the-art solution to address the need for integrating the business and ICS network. The solution requires a very small agent to be installed on the ICS equipment. Which of the following is the MOST important security control for the manager to invest in to protect the facility?

comments.content: Do you think that the solution provider will be giving you the source code?

discussion.content: Even if it was just for testing, would monitoring the activity be better than analyzing the source code ?

I have doubts with D.

D. Install the agent for a week on a test system and monitor the activities. - Not all activities will be visible. What if there's a code in the agent which will only trigger after a specific event, or time (lets say after a week or month), then it won't be seen.

Whereas, letter A, will give us vulnerabilities and weaknesses of the agent, that will allow us to patch/mitigate/create necessary security controls to harden/protect it from attacks

B and C doesn't do much also.

comments.content: Or even a sandbox test even.*
I agree with u
Yeah but A implies that the agent is already installed on a production system, I think. D seems to hint at testing in the development phase.

choices.B: Require that the solution provider make the agent source code available for analysis.
choices.C: Require thorough guides for administrator and users.
choices.D: Install the agent for a week on a test system and monitor the activities.
choices.A: Run a penetration test on the installed agent.

discussion.content:
I don't think implementing WPAv2 necessarily stops downgrade attacks. The whole point of the downgrade attack is to take a system that uses a strong cipher suite and try and trick it into using something weaker.

I think it has to be B.

Keyword here is WPA2 which is modern more secured...moving to this means trying to avoid attackers exploiting the old less secured WPA...
and the question also said..what are they trying to mitigate against by switching to WPA2

comments.content: But do you realise that the question never mentions a WPA. The emphasis here seems to be on password attacks. Using long passphrase and changing them every month.
Rainbow tables attempt to crack the password hash. So frequently changing it and And making it longer will make cracking it more difficult. B is correct.
I agree. Downgrade attack doesn’t make sense here.
Agreed. Here's some interesting read: https://security.stackexchange.com/questions/92903/rainbow-tables-hash-tables-versus-wpa-wpa2

discussion.content: why A ? Shouldn't be B ?

questions.question_text: A company has implemented WPA2, a 20-character minimum for the WiFi passphrase, and a new WiFi passphrase every 30 days, and has disabled SSID broadcast on all wireless access points. Which of the following is the company trying to mitigate?

choices.A: Power off the computer and remove it from the network.
choices.C: Perform a physical hard disk image.
choices.B: Unplug the network cable and take screenshots of the desktop.

questions.question_text: During an investigation, a computer is being seized. Which of the following is the FIRST step the analyst should take?

comments.content: Yes but what does that mean though. Do you first initiate the chain of custody, or do you first power down the machine? Both these steps come before collecting data. I'm still confused.

discussion.content: “Before the analyst begins to collect any data, a decision should be made by the analyst or management (in accordance with the organizationís policies and legal advisors) on the need to collect and preserve evidence in a way that supports its use in future legal or internal disciplinary proceedings. In such situations, a clearly defined chain of custody should be followed to avoid allegations of mishandling or tampering of evidence.” - https://nvlpubs.nist.gov/nistpubs/Legacy/SP/nistspecialpublication800-86.pdf#page25
Definitely not A, you don't power off the computer - you will lose the potential evidence in cache and RAM. I think D is the correct answer.
I would go with B - As comp is to be isolated from network first and then taking images while making chain of custody.

1) Seizure

The seizure step involves marking the elements that will be used in later processes. Photographs of the scene and notes are taken. An important question to answer in this phase is whether or not to pull the plug on the network. Leaving the system online while proceeding may alert the attacker, allowing him to wipe the attack traces and destroy evidences. The attacker may also leave a dead man switch, which destroys the evidence once the system goes offline. In such circumstances, it may be necessary or advisable for to gather evidence from the system while it is running or in a live state, being fully aware that this causes changes to the system and reasons for taking this approach must be explained.

https://resources.infosecinstitute.com/category/computerforensics/introduction/areas-of-study/forensic-science/forensic-analysis-and-examination-planning/
It's A...If you don't power off the computer, there is a risk that some data can be deleted and the evidence is gone, so before you take any further steps, turn off and disconnect from the net..

If you are at the point of Incident Containment, you have already imaged the disk drive, hashed and established a chain of custody. Seizing the computer, as I am interpreting it, is a possible part of the containment stage. Removing the computer from the network completely, is the most extreme form of containment. This question plays with semantics, I am not a fan of it.

comments.content:
Nope, I am back to C. Image the Hard Disk Drive.

 "A computer that is running at the time of seizure should not be allowed to shut down, pulling the plug out of the wall will prevent any programs from wiping incriminating information during the shutdown sequence. The computer forensic expert can test the shutdown sequence later, to see if it includes any destructive programs."

http://www.datatriage.com/computer-forensic-seizing-the-evidence/
I found this: https://www.oas.org/juridico/spanish/cyb_best_pract.pdf. It doesn't look official, but it does more or less say the same thing.

discussion.content:
Correct me if I'm wrong, I'm not a digital forensic analyst:
1. First you'd determine what data needs to be collected.
2. Optional: In some cases, you'd want to collect volatile memory which would otherwise disappear if you power down the computer. Let's assume we're skipping this step because it's not important.
3. You power down the computer (in some cases, you'd even unplug the power cable to prevent shutdown scripts from executing).
4. From that point on, the computer is a piece of evidence, and a chain of custody document should be started.

So it might be A after all. But then again, I'm no DFA and I can't really find any conclusive information about this topic anywhere... .
actually not D on second thoughts: It's being seized so yes, you power it off and remove it. That's what seized means. Normally in forensics, however, one wouldn't power it off due to data volatility

comments.content: But should it be that literal? If the question is asked non non-security/non-technical guys, surely they must power it off. But since we're studying cysa here, i think D is the best choice?

discussion.content: Surely D
I think D also, closely followed by C.

comments.content: Do we initiate chain of custody documentation first before doing the forensic image? Or the other way around? Can you also share some references? Thank you

discussion.content: D or C... cant be A surely
I want to go with D on this
